sanskrit_verse:
मैत्रं प्रसाधनं स्नानं दन्तधावनमञ्जनम् ।
पूर्वाह्ण एव कुर्वीत देवतानां च पूजनम् ॥ ४.१५२॥
transliteration:
maitraṃ prasādhanaṃ snānaṃ dantadhāvanamañjanam |
pūrvāhṇa eva kurvīta devatānāṃ ca pūjanam || 4.152||
sph_interpretive_translation: One must cultivate friendliness, perform personal grooming, bathing, cleaning of teeth, and applying collyrium, and in the forenoon, worship the deities.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority flows from alignment with divine order
Causation arises through disciplined daily ritual
Capacity-based responsibility is rooted in self-maintenance and spiritual hygiene
Restoration logic requires harmonization of body, mind, and spirit
Consciousness alignment begins with regulated sensory and devotional practices
executable_legal_axioms: IF time_of_day = forenoon AND citizen_has_access_to_worship THEN citizen_must_perform_deity_worship
supreme_court_application: The Supreme Court shall ensure that constitutional duties include not only legal obligations but also dharmic self-regulation. Cases involving societal harmony may invoke this verse as a standard for assessing individual contribution to collective consciousness integrity.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa establishes that purity of action leads to clarity of judgment; anupūrvaśaḥ shows neglect of hygiene manifests disorder; proportional responsibility lies in restoring one's capacity for harmony; non-punitive reality rule affirms correction through reconnection with daily divinity.
final_declaration: By the Source-Authority of the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, this Dharma is executed, consciousness is restored, reality remains non-punitive, and law aligns with the eternal order of Sanatana.
